creator.name: Joe Brewer
creator.bio: I am a change strategist working on behalf of humanity, and also a complexity researcher, cognitive scientist, and evangelist for the field of culture design.

paragraphs.name: 3a19
paragraphs.text: Why Billionaires Are Incapable of Compassion

When we hear about massive corruption in an unequal society, it is quite natural to blame the super rich… but what if they too are being hurt by this inhumanely exploitative economic system? Should we try to heal them too?

paragraphs.name: 65db
paragraphs.text: I have been writing a lot lately about the mental disease plaguing millions of people around the world as the capitalist system goes through a massive dying process. This has caused intense feelings of anxiety, shame, and humiliation for all the people who “followed the rules” — studying hard in school, filling out countless job applications, and still being under-employed even when they are lucky enough to get a job.

paragraphs.name: b1c9
paragraphs.text: If we are to take seriously the call to be healers, not warriors, in this transition from one economic system to another, we will need to reflect on the psychological harms wrought on the billionaire class in a world that is driven by mindless consumption and an insatiable desire to hoard wealth.

paragraphs.name: d4fe
paragraphs.text: Just yesterday I read another article about the thieving of trillions of dollars that have been squirreled away in tax havens, kept from recirculating in the economy through tax cuts for the rich, and hidden within a Russian doll meshwork of shell companies owning other shell companies to launder the money. This is how it came to pass that a mere 62 people have the same aggregate wealth as 3.7 billion.

paragraphs.name: b8dd
paragraphs.text: I just happen to know a few billionaires personally. In my line of work as a culture designer who works on large-scale social change I have the opportunity to sit in many different rooms with strange cohorts of people. So it has happened on a few occasions that I’ve sat down with individuals who are obscenely rich and thoroughly disconnected from the normal world or daily lives of most people on the planet.
Here is what I’ve observed:

paragraphs.name: ca1d
paragraphs.text: These billionaires are spiritually depleted, emotionally hollow people. They are constantly feeling the pressure to fit in among other absurdly rich individuals in a constant game of oneupmanship — impressing those who have had it all and can no longer be impressed. It is soul-sucking and psychologically damaging to live in this kind of world. These people are structurally incapable of feeling compassion for the masses (as it is their own core insecurities that keep them self-focused on power and greed).

paragraphs.name: a730
paragraphs.text: Said another way, they are plagued with the disease of NEVER BEING ABLE TO HAVE ENOUGH.

Think about what this does to a person. As the global population becomes more unequal in wealth, while the planet heats up from excessive industrial pollution, while billions starve to death or barely scrape out a desperate living — these people continue to buy more yachts, collect mansions as if they were playing cards, and try to stab each other in the back to hoard away more status relative to each other.

paragraphs.name: 06ea
paragraphs.text: It is the same sickness. In the end game of wealth hoarding, there are no winners.

paragraphs.name: 768f
paragraphs.text: I have participated in social movements against the super rich. I count among my friends the people who organized Occupy Wall Street, peasant farmers trying to take back their land from multinational corporations in India and Latin America, researchers who study tax havens and the global architecture of wealth extraction, and many more who strive to change this morally bankrupt economic system.

paragraphs.name: 31af
paragraphs.text: So this is a difficult thing for me to say. Yet here I am saying it. The billionaires are not the enemy. Our true enemy is a mindset, a worldview with sacred beliefs that treat money as if it were a god and that confuses the accumulation of wealth for happiness and fulfillment. We are living through the end of empire — if we go back to the very beginnings of agriculture 10,000 years ago we see the pattern of domination and conquest that has now spread to encompass the entire planet.

paragraphs.name: 1b03
paragraphs.text: The end game for such a cancer is either to kill its host (collapse our civilization) or destroy itself and leave the host intact (leaving seeds of transformation to be planted in the fertile soil that remains). I call for the seeds of transformation. This is the future I want to help build in my lifetime. It is the only option that is worthy of my heart and soul.

paragraphs.name: 05c8
paragraphs.text: Before we can begin this difficult work together as a human race working at the planetary scale, we must practice the Art of Systemic Thinking. This includes seeing that the economic mindset that hurts the poor and middle classes also brings with it a psychic trauma upon those who were most susceptible to the great lie that money brings happiness.

paragraphs.name: 45b9
paragraphs.text: This plague upon the minds of the super rich is what silences their hearts and blinds them to their role in buying off politicians, spreading lies about the science of our planet’s health, and continuing to cling to their delusions that somehow they deserve their place at the top of a toxic pyramid or that this is even a desirable position to covet in a dying world order.

paragraphs.name: 85dd
paragraphs.text: We need to heal our billionaires just as much as we need to heal ourselves.

paragraphs.name: 9a5d
paragraphs.text: Onward, fellow humans.
